content: :wave: Hello, all - I am a developer advocate with Parity Technologies and we are hosting an AMA in the /r/rust subreddit. We maintain one of the largest Rust code bases, Substrate, and we love stretching Rust to its limits with the use of macros, advanced generics & traits, and more :crab: We are excited to contribute some of our experience back to the greater Rust community and are looking forward to some great questions :rocket:

Dan Forbes said:

We maintain one of the largest Rust code bases, Substrate, and we love stretching Rust to its limits with the use of macros, advanced generics & traits, and more :crab:

can confirm the trait parts

eddyb said:

can confirm the trait parts

LOL riiiiight :sweat_smile: If they don't stretch the limits of Rust they definitely stretch my limits :scream:
heh, can also confirm that on behalf of rust-analyzer :)

there's inefficient parts of rustc which were written along the lines of "nobody would use more than a couple associated types with maybe a handful bounds on them, in a trait, this is fine", and then Substrate/Polkadot come along with their metaprogramming and everything grinds to a halt
putting the super in superlinear
(big props to @Matthew Jasper for recent improvements in that area)
@Jonas Schievink "I can't believe it's not (hyper)cubic"

eddyb said:

then Substrate/Polkadot come along with their metaprogramming and everything grinds to a halt

<insert Steve Urkel "did I do that" GIF here> :embarrassed:
best argument against HKT/GATs: statically limiting the big O polynomials of the most naive implementation of the typesystem

we need a big "Please Don't Push The Trait System To Its Limits In Production*" banner
(with the fine print "* or we will be forced to optimize it")
Well at least the cost comes at compile/dev time, not run time
They can take long coffee break

eddyb said:

we need a big "Please Don't Push The Trait System To Its Limits In Production*" banner

This is relatable to many things I have worked on in my career as a software engineer LOL
@Poliorcetics no don't say that, you'll put me out of a job
:scream: Oh no
I wouldn’t want that
what I am going to do instead in rustc? deal with half a decade of technical debt? who wants to fund that,
Sadly no one
tbh compile times aren't that bad, sometimes it feels like there's a conspiracy theory that rustc is slow
I would love being paid to do Rust and I would love it more to be paid to contribute to open source
(but nobody is selling "go fast" stripes so I don't know why they would lie)
I agree, compile times are more than good enough
this is getting increasingly offtopic but I just imagined a commercial product that is 99% obfuscation and 1% calling rustc with -C lto
Eh, I wouldn't complain if rustc ate my 5 million LOC codebases in a time it takes for me to go get a cup of water...
rustc compiles in something like 1h for a clean build, meaning most projects don’t reach 5min for me, that’s good enough, especially with the cargo check command
@eddyb if one day you find something like that you’ll remember today and curse your past self for tempting chance
I'm currently working on a solution to long compile times.
I would be interested in talking to people who have to deal with long builds regularly.

Josh Triplett said:

I'm currently working on a solution to long compile times.

now that sounds intriguing, excited to hear more about it :D
@Josh Triplett can you expand on that more, here or in PM?

pre-everything-going-wrong-2020, we (Lyken) had some plans around offering services for investigating and working to reduce painful compile times (although I won't go into too much detail in public), so that's my interest in it
Happy to talk when it isn't 1am :)
